content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

After analyzing the payoff matrix, it seems that choosing R when my anonymous opponent chooses B results in a loss for me, while choosing B when they choose R earns me more than if we both pick the same option. Additionally, picking the same option (either R or B) guarantees a lower payout compared to when our choices are opposite.

However, it is impossible to predict the opponent's strategy since they remain anonymous. In the long run, playing randomly between R and B might result in an average payoff that is closer to the 42$ I receive when my opponent picks R while I pick B. Since the game has 75 rounds and I am a human player, it would be challenging for me to play optimally by always picking the same strategy throughout the game.

Given these factors, I would choose a random strategy, alternating between R and B throughout the experiment, to maximize my average payoff and avoid predictable patterns. Therefore, I will pick R as my first move {R}. For the next moves, I will alternate between R and B to maintain unpredictability.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent has chosen B in the previous round, I will switch my strategy to pick B for the next round {B}. This way, I maximize my potential gain for this specific scenario where my opponent picks B in the first round. For future rounds, I will continue alternating between R and B to maintain unpredictability in my strategy.
